segment.source: Create a rule that uses a publisher condition (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a rule that uses a publisher condition (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a publisher condition.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a publisher condition.

segment.source: Create a rule that uses a publisher condition
segment.target: Create a rule that uses a publisher condition

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a publisher condition.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a publisher condition.

segment.source: You can use publisher conditions only for files that are digitally signed; the publisher condition identifies an app based on its digital signature and extended attributes.
segment.target: You can use publisher conditions only for files that are digitally signed; the publisher condition identifies an app based on its digital signature and extended attributes.

segment.source: The digital signature contains information about the company that created the app (the publisher).
segment.target: The digital signature contains information about the company that created the app (the publisher).

segment.source: The extended attributes, which are obtained from the binary resource, contain the name of the product that the file is part of and the version number of the application.
segment.target: The extended attributes, which are obtained from the binary resource, contain the name of the product that the file is part of and the version number of the application.

segment.source: The publisher may be a software development company, such as Microsoft, or the information technology department of your organization.
segment.target: The publisher may be a software development company, such as Microsoft, or the information technology department of your organization.

segment.source: Packaged app rules are by definition rules that use publisher conditions.
segment.target: Packaged app rules are by definition rules that use publisher conditions.

segment.source: For info about creating a packaged app rule, see Create a rule for packaged apps.
segment.target: For info about creating a packaged app rule, see Create a rule for packaged apps.

segment.source: For info about the publisher condition, see Understanding the publisher rule condition in AppLocker.
segment.target: For info about the publisher condition, see Understanding the publisher rule condition in AppLocker.

segment.source: You can perform this task by using the Group Policy Management Console for an AppLocker policy in a Group Policy Object (GPO) or by using the Local Security Policy snap-in for an AppLocker policy on a local computer or in a security template.
segment.target: You can perform this task by using the Group Policy Management Console for an AppLocker policy in a Group Policy Object (GPO) or by using the Local Security Policy snap-in for an AppLocker policy on a local computer or in a security template.

segment.source: For info how to use these MMC snap-ins to administer AppLocker, see Administer AppLocker.
segment.target: For info how to use these MMC snap-ins to administer AppLocker, see Administer AppLocker.

segment.source: To create a new rule with a publisher condition
segment.target: To create a new rule with a publisher condition

segment.source: Open the AppLocker console, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.
segment.target: Open the AppLocker console, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.

segment.source: On the Action menu, click Create New Rule.
segment.target: On the Action menu, click Create New Rule.

segment.source: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Permissions page, select the action (allow or deny) and the user or group that the rule should apply to, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Permissions page, select the action (allow or deny) and the user or group that the rule should apply to, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Conditions page, select the Publisher rule condition, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Conditions page, select the Publisher rule condition, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Publisher page, click Browse to select a signed file, and then use the slider to specify the scope of the rule.
segment.target: On the Publisher page, click Browse to select a signed file, and then use the slider to specify the scope of the rule.

segment.source: To use custom values in any of the fields or to specify a specific file version, select the Use custom values check box.
segment.target: To use custom values in any of the fields or to specify a specific file version, select the Use custom values check box.

segment.source: For example, you can use the asterisk () wildcard character within a publisher rule to specify that any value should be matched.
segment.target: For example, you can use the asterisk () wildcard character within a publisher rule to specify that any value should be matched.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: (Optional) On the Exceptions page, specify conditions by which to exclude files from being affected by the rule.
segment.target: (Optional) On the Exceptions page, specify conditions by which to exclude files from being affected by the rule.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the Name page, either accept the automatically generated rule name or type a new rule name, and then click Create.
segment.target: On the Name page, either accept the automatically generated rule name or type a new rule name, and then click Create.
